awd_titl_txt: PROMISE: A Platform for Competition and Education in Cyber Security
awd_abstract_narration:
Cybersecurity competitions are an important component in security education and research, as they complement and enhance traditional pedagogical approaches. However, the benefits of security competitions may not be fully realized without addressing a few challenges in current security education including lack of competent training facilities and shortage of appropriate and shareable training materials that cater to security novices. Moreover, security competitions may be perceived as a burden to the many two or four year teaching institutions that lack the necessary resources. As a result, these institutions miss an opportunity to engage a large population of young talent in cybersecurity.

This research project seeks to address those challenges by developing a novel, virtual platform for both competition and education, namely PROMISE (Platform for Competition and Education in Cyber Security), and a set of learning and competition modules using the platform. Built on top of state-of-the-art, open-source cloud computing systems, the PROMISE platform is scalable and flexible and supports competitions of different styles as well as hands-on security puzzles, labs and projects, which makes it a versatile facility for both security competition and general education and research. The learning modules cover a variety of important security topics and each of them has four levels of content (including concept level content for learners with little security background) to engage learners with different backgrounds and interests. By sharing developed software and learning materials, collaborating with diverse institutions such as high schools and community colleges, and organizing cyber-defense competitions and professional development workshop, this project is expected to make both immediate and long-term impacts on cyber security competition and education.

por.por_cntn:
The Cyber Arena provides an open-source application for cybersecurity skills development using cloud resources. Over 50 computing environments known as ?workouts? are specified to cover over 11 different topic areas, including network security, web application security, cryptography, and digital forensics. These workouts are designed at the beginner level with add-on challenges to target multiple skill levels in the same classroom.

Because the Cyber Arena is an infrastructure-as-code application, any institution can deploy their own branded instance of the Cyber Arena through a cloud project (currently, only Google Cloud is supported) and a managed DNS zone. Once built, educators can be designated to build any of the 50 pre-specified workouts on-demand through the authenticated web application (included in the deployment). A workout may be specified as either a complete virtual network, a container application, or a competition environment. Assessment questions are available for multiple skill levels, and auto-assessment is available when students complete particular technical objectives.

The pre-specified workouts are mapped to the NICE framework to support educators in identifying workouts that meet their curriculum needs. Furthermore, educators have the tools to build and share their workouts when a pre-specified workout does not meet the learning objective.

Each student accesses the Cyber Arena through any computing browser by navigating to a publicly accessible web page. Students authenticate to the web page using credentials arbitrarily generated during the build and access all computing resources through the web application. In this way, students do not need any specialized hardware or additional software loaded on their computers. In addition, when the Cyber Arena is used for a conference or other special tutorial, a link is generated for students to self-register for their workout.

Additionally, institutions can provide administrative support for their Cyber Arena deployment through the main web application. Educational technology services can monitor the mass deployment of workouts and troubleshoot common issues students and educators may have in the deployment and use of the workouts.

The Cyber Arena is a proven technology already tested in multiple educational environments, including secondary schools, universities, apprenticeship programs, and private sector training. The application automates the building and tearing down of cloud resources to optimize the cost of deployment. As a result, large-scale implementations for hundreds of students cost less than a few thousand dollars a year in metered cloud costs. The open-source project complete with build instructions and documentation can be found at https://github.com/emerginganalytics/cyberarena.
